title: How to Barbeque a Fish Directly on Charcoal

steps.headline: Gather some wood for a fire.
steps.description: Use branches from trees that are used for firewood. Do not use lumber because they might be chemically treated.

steps.headline: Fire up the wood, let it burn down and wait until the coals are glowing.
Choose what to cook.
steps.description: Save your prized catch for home cooking and pick a fish that is average to good in taste because there will be some wastage. Do not pick a fish with thin skin and small scales like a mackerel. An average tasting fish will taste good when cooked on charcoal and outdoors.

steps.headline: Without scaling, skinning or gutting the fish, put it directly on the charcoal.
steps.description: The scale or thick skin will protect the meat from burning. After a while, the aroma of wood burning and fish cooking will be quite appealing.

steps.headline: Do not overcook, fish cook fast and even faster directly on charcoal.
steps.description: After turning the fish over, do not cook it too long. Like cooking in a pan, the first side takes longer to cook. Poke at the fish with a fork to test if it its cooked, if the fork does not go in - let it cook longer.

steps.headline: Peel the meat off of the centre bones and separate it from the charred exterior.
Enjoy the fish with whatever seasoning or condiment packages available  or use partially dried salt from a salt water pool.

text: Gather some wood for a fire. Use branches from trees that are used for firewood. Do not use lumber because they might be chemically treated. Fire up the wood, let it burn down and wait until the coals are glowing.  Choose what to cook. Save your prized catch for home cooking and pick a fish that is average to good in taste because there will be some wastage. Do not pick a fish with thin skin and small scales like a mackerel. An average tasting fish will taste good when cooked on charcoal and outdoors. Without scaling, skinning or gutting the fish, put it directly on the charcoal. The scale or thick skin will protect the meat from burning. After a while, the aroma of wood burning and fish cooking will be quite appealing. Do not overcook, fish cook fast and even faster directly on charcoal. After turning the fish over, do not cook it too long. Like cooking in a pan, the first side takes longer to cook. Poke at the fish with a fork to test if it its cooked, if the fork does not go in - let it cook longer. Peel the meat off of the centre bones and separate it from the charred exterior. Discard the charred exterior. Enjoy the fish with whatever seasoning or condiment packages available  or use partially dried salt from a salt water pool.
